newsitem.title: USA: Coast Guard not expanding Mississippi safety zone.
newsitem.headline: Coast Guard not expanding Mississippi safety zone.

text.p: The U.S. Coast Guard said it does not plan to expand the approximate 240-mile safety zone it has imposed on the upper Mississippi this week but was closely watching the high water levels in that area.
"We have not expanded the zone," said Lt Drew Cheney, assistant Chief of Port Operations, Coast Guard Marine Safety Office, St Louis.
High waters and potential flooding prompted the Coast Guard to close navigation from River Mile 615.1 at Guttenberg, Iowa to River Mile 857.6 at Minneapolis, Minn, late Wednesday.
"We are allowing some barge movement on a case-by-case basis." But for the most part, barge traffic was restricted. "Navigation was closed primarily for safety reasons," he said.
But Cheney noted a possibility of other pockets that need navigation restrictions because of the structure of the levees and low-lying areas which are vulnerable to flooding.

Cheney said the Mississippi River at Minneapolis was expected to crest on Saturday at 19 feet, three feet above the 16-feet flood stage and at 21 to 22 feet at St Paul, Minn., eight feet above the 14-feet flood stage.
Rising water levels may close another lock on Friday on the upper Mississippi, river officials said.

"Lock and Dam 6 near Trempealeau, Wis., may close on April 11 due to high water," said Teri Alberico, administrative assistant with the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers, St Paul, Minn. "That is the estimated closing date. But we have not made that decision yet,"
The Corps said it expected to close Lock and Dam 8 (Genoa, Wis) on April 14, Lock and Dam No. 9 (at Eastman, Wis.) on April 15 and Lock and Dam No. 10 (Guttenberg, Iowa) on April 16.
So far, eight locks have been closed from upper and lower St Anthony Falls, Minn, and south to Lock and Dam 5A at Fountain City, Wis., the Corps said.
